Title.evidence: Title: Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation for Intermittent Claudication: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: A sample size of 192 was calculated to detect a 60 m difference in AWD with 90% power.

Participants.evidence: Participants with IC were randomised 1:1 to receive either NMES plus local standard care or local standard care alone.

Intervention.evidence: Participants with IC were randomised 1:1 to receive either NMES plus local standard care or local standard care alone.

Objective.evidence: This trial assessed the efficacy of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) as an adjunct to standard care in improving walking distances.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in absolute walking distance (AWD) at 3 months, measured by a standardised treadmill test.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: From February 2018 to March 2020, 200 participants were randomised; 100 to NMES and 100 to control.

Result_Outcome.evidence: NMES showed no significant improvement in AWD (0.83 units; 95% CI, −0.67 to 2.34; p = 0.28).

Harms.evidence: No device-related serious adverse events were reported.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Efficacy and Mechanism Evaluation Program, Medical Research Council, and National Institute for Health and Care Research.
